Description: Fragment of the lid of a Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; cream slip; interior reserved; exterior: from centre, part of tongue frieze surrounding now lost knob; two narrow bands; black-figure decoration consisting of bull (body with added red, part of tail and neck remaining) to right; tail of second animal perhaps at left edge; squat (almost flat) pendant rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Stage 2 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless. The vases in Stage 2 have even more basic rosettes than the vases from Stage 1. Furthermore, the deterioration of the Sphinx and Lion Style appears quite clearly in the execution of the face of the different figures. According to Boardman, the sherd might belong to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.120.12.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 148, p. 315, no. 1351, pl. 174)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 35, no. 62, pl. XVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2114) (phase 2)
